values.description:
I mentioned that I would update the MulticopterMotorModel style after pull request #322 was merged, but I had forgotten to do it.

* #!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/pull-requests/322/blueprint-multicopter-motor-model/diff#comment-102009314

So, this updates the style so that clang-tidy is happy. I also threw in one small performance improvement to the physics system (using a const reference for a local `sdf::Collision` instance).
values.title: Fix MulticopterMotorModel style per clang-tidy

summary.raw:
I mentioned that I would update the MulticopterMotorModel style after pull request #322 was merged, but I had forgotten to do it.

* #!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/pull-requests/322/blueprint-multicopter-motor-model/diff#comment-102009314

So, this updates the style so that clang-tidy is happy. I also threw in one small performance improvement to the physics system (using a const reference for a local `sdf::Collision` instance).
summary.html:
I mentioned that I would update the MulticopterMotorModel style after pull request #322 was merged, but I had forgotten to do it.

  • #!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/pull-requests/322/blueprint-multicopter-motor-model/diff#comment-102009314

So, this updates the style so that clang-tidy is happy. I also threw in one small performance improvement to the physics system (using a const reference for a local sdf::Collision instance).

values.description:
* This removes creation of entities from the LogPlayback system. Entities will be created as the ECM is populated from serialized state.
* This also sets `ComponentState::PeriodicChange` on entities that have updated poses.
* The LevelManager is updated to only process the default level if `useLevels` is turned off. This fixes the unintended interaction between the level manager and log playback

Note that when running log playback, the simulation has to be started before anything shows up on the screen.
values.title: Fix log playback with levels

summary.raw:
* This removes creation of entities from the LogPlayback system. Entities will be created as the ECM is populated from serialized state.
* This also sets `ComponentState::PeriodicChange` on entities that have updated poses.
* The LevelManager is updated to only process the default level if `useLevels` is turned off. This fixes the unintended interaction between the level manager and log playback

Note that when running log playback, the simulation has to be started before anything shows up on the screen.
summary.html:
• This removes creation of entities from the LogPlayback system. Entities will be created as the ECM is populated from serialized state.
  • This also sets ComponentState::PeriodicChange on entities that have updated poses.
  • The LevelManager is updated to only process the default level if useLevels is turned off. This fixes the unintended interaction between the level manager and log playback

Note that when running log playback, the simulation has to be started before anything shows up on the screen.

values.description:
Some new features will be landing on `ign-rendering3` soon, and if we want to use them on `ign-gazebo3`, we need to update the whole dependency chain not to depend on `ign-rendering2`.

Repos affected: `ign-sensors`, `ign-gui`, `ign-gazebo`

values.description:
1. Move creation of default log path to ServerConfig. This lets both console logs and state logs to be stored in the same directory.
2. The console messages are always logged.
3. Allow state log files to be overwritten.

Requires: #!/ignitionrobotics/ign-common/pull-requests/203
values.title: Log console messages, and support co-location of state and console logs

summary.raw:
1. Move creation of default log path to ServerConfig. This lets both console logs and state logs to be stored in the same directory.
2. The console messages are always logged.
3. Allow state log files to be overwritten.

Requires: #!/ignitionrobotics/ign-common/pull-requests/203
summary.html:
1. Move creation of default log path to ServerConfig. This lets both console logs and state logs to be stored in the same directory.
  2. The console messages are always logged.
  3. Allow state log files to be overwritten.

Requires: #!/ignitionrobotics/ign-common/pull-requests/203

values.description:
This PR, together with[ ign-rendering PR](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-rendering/pull-requests/184), [ign-common PR](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-common/pull-requests/197), and [ign-msgs PR](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-msgs/pull-requests/147), add support for Actor in ign-gazebo. The actor can be animated by the COLLODA and BVH files. It can also following predefined trajectories, see the demo below \(running `ign gazebo actor.sdf`\):

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/gyKEbkz/images/33103885-gazebo_sequence.gif)
The demo shows the actor \(bald man\) takes multiple animations \(standing, sitting down, sitting, standing up, walking, running and gesturing\).
values.title: rendering and animating Actor

summary.raw:
This PR, together with[ ign-rendering PR](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-rendering/pull-requests/184), [ign-common PR](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-common/pull-requests/197), and [ign-msgs PR](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-msgs/pull-requests/147), add support for Actor in ign-gazebo. The actor can be animated by the COLLODA and BVH files. It can also following predefined trajectories, see the demo below \(running `ign gazebo actor.sdf`\):

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/gyKEbkz/images/33103885-gazebo_sequence.gif)
The demo shows the actor \(bald man\) takes multiple animations \(standing, sitting down, sitting, standing up, walking, running and gesturing\).
summary.html:
This PR, together with ign-rendering PR, ign-common PR, and ign-msgs PR, add support for Actor in ign-gazebo. The actor can be animated by the COLLODA and BVH files. It can also following predefined trajectories, see the demo below (running ign gazebo actor.sdf):

The demo shows the actor (bald man) takes multiple animations (standing, sitting down, sitting, standing up, walking, running and gesturing).

values.description:
Requests for adding and removing entities are queued in RenderUtil and processed before a render call. Problem is that requests are not timestamped. So if there is a request to remove and add the same entity in between two render updates, the order of which they are processed could be incorrect and can lead to a crash.

This PR tags the requests with the current simulation iteration and use that to determine how they should be processed.
values.title: Fix order of adding and removing rendering entities

summary.raw:
Requests for adding and removing entities are queued in RenderUtil and processed before a render call. Problem is that requests are not timestamped. So if there is a request to remove and add the same entity in between two render updates, the order of which they are processed could be incorrect and can lead to a crash.

This PR tags the requests with the current simulation iteration and use that to determine how they should be processed.
summary.html:
Requests for adding and removing entities are queued in RenderUtil and processed before a render call. Problem is that requests are not timestamped. So if there is a request to remove and add the same entity in between two render updates, the order of which they are processed could be incorrect and can lead to a crash.

This PR tags the requests with the current simulation iteration and use that to determine how they should be processed.

values.description:
When setting a material to a mesh, the material is cloned and the copy is assigned. That leaves the original material dangling inside ign-rendering.

A proper fix in ign-rendering may break ABI so here’s a workaround to destroy it after use in ign-gazebo.
values.title: Clean up mesh material in rendering

summary.raw:
When setting a material to a mesh, the material is cloned and the copy is assigned. That leaves the original material dangling inside ign-rendering.

A proper fix in ign-rendering may break ABI so here’s a workaround to destroy it after use in ign-gazebo.
summary.html:
When setting a material to a mesh, the material is cloned and the copy is assigned. That leaves the original material dangling inside ign-rendering.

A proper fix in ign-rendering may break ABI so here’s a workaround to destroy it after use in ign-gazebo.

values.description:
Since we added ERB support to the CLI, we've been passing the world SDF string to `Server`, so we don't hit [this line](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/src/736f7a248438ffa0713e6dd30eb4450318fa9f6b/src/Server.cc#lines-164) that prints the file path anymore.

This change prints the world file path even when using the cli:

~~~
$ ign gazebo -v 4 shapes.sdf                                                                         
[Msg] Ignition Gazebo GUI    v2.7.1                                                                                        
[Msg] Ignition Gazebo Server v2.7.1                                                                                         
[Msg] Loading SDF world file[/home/developer/ws/install/share/ignition/ignition-gazebo2/worlds/shapes.sdf].
~~~

If a config is passed to the server which has both the XML and the file path, the XML is used.
values.title: Print world path when using cli

summary.raw:
Since we added ERB support to the CLI, we've been passing the world SDF string to `Server`, so we don't hit [this line](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/src/736f7a248438ffa0713e6dd30eb4450318fa9f6b/src/Server.cc#lines-164) that prints the file path anymore.

This change prints the world file path even when using the cli:

~~~
$ ign gazebo -v 4 shapes.sdf                                                                         
[Msg] Ignition Gazebo GUI    v2.7.1                                                                                        
[Msg] Ignition Gazebo Server v2.7.1                                                                                         
[Msg] Loading SDF world file[/home/developer/ws/install/share/ignition/ignition-gazebo2/worlds/shapes.sdf].
~~~

If a config is passed to the server which has both the XML and the file path, the XML is used.
summary.html:
Since we added ERB support to the CLI, we've been passing the world SDF string to Server, so we don't hit this line that prints the file path anymore.

This change prints the world file path even when using the cli:

$ ign gazebo -v 4 shapes.sdf                                                                         
[Msg] Ignition Gazebo GUI    v2.7.1                                                                                        
[Msg] Ignition Gazebo Server v2.7.1                                                                                         
[Msg] Loading SDF world file[/home/developer/ws/install/share/ignition/ignition-gazebo2/worlds/shapes.sdf].

If a config is passed to the server which has both the XML and the file path, the XML is used.

values.description:
Requires ign-physics [PR #100](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-physics/pull-requests/100?w=1).

This affects all systems that use the `JointVelocityCmd` component. Using the `JointSetVelocityCommandFeature`, avoids interfering with the internal state of the physics engine to set the joint velocity. Instead, the appropriate force to achieve the commanded velocity is computed and applied on the joint.
values.title: Use the JointSetVelocityCommand feature to set joint velocities

summary.raw:
Requires ign-physics [PR #100](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-physics/pull-requests/100?w=1).

This affects all systems that use the `JointVelocityCmd` component. Using the `JointSetVelocityCommandFeature`, avoids interfering with the internal state of the physics engine to set the joint velocity. Instead, the appropriate force to achieve the commanded velocity is computed and applied on the joint.
summary.html:
Requires ign-physics PR #100.

This affects all systems that use the JointVelocityCmd component. Using the JointSetVelocityCommandFeature, avoids interfering with the internal state of the physics engine to set the joint velocity. Instead, the appropriate force to achieve the commanded velocity is computed and applied on the joint.

values.description:
The Move To feature moves the user camera in the 3D scene to the selected entity.

To use: Right click on a model in the 3D scene or entity tree and select move to.

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8zodKzn/images/3011493744-move_to.gif)
‌

The context menu is implemented as a QML module that’s used by both the scene3d and entity\_tree plugin.

TODOs:

* The Visual class in ign-rendering currently does not have a BoundingBox\(\) function that’s needed for adjusting the final camera position so that the entire model fits in the camera view. The bounding box is hard coded to \[1, 1, 1\] for now. Need to add this function in ign-rendering3
* A `MoveToHelper` class is added in scene3d plugin. Its functionality should be ported to the rendering::Camera class in ign-rendering3
values.title: Add Move To gui plugin

The Move To feature moves the user camera in the 3D scene to the selected entity.

To use: Right click on a model in the 3D scene or entity tree and select move to.

‌

The context menu is implemented as a QML module that’s used by both the scene3d and entity_tree plugin.

TODOs:

  • The Visual class in ign-rendering currently does not have a BoundingBox() function that’s needed for adjusting the final camera position so that the entire model fits in the camera view. The bounding box is hard coded to [1, 1, 1] for now. Need to add this function in ign-rendering3
  • A MoveToHelper class is added in scene3d plugin. Its functionality should be ported to the rendering::Camera class in ign-rendering3

values.description:
Allow customizing odometry publish frequency and use sim time to throttle. Still defaults to 50Hz.

Try:

`ign gazebo -v 4 diff_drive.sdf`

The blue vehicle should be publishing at 1Hz:

`ign topic -e -t /model/vehicle_blue/odometry`

The green vehicle at 50 Hz:

`ign topic -e -t /model/vehicle_green/odometry`
values.title: Custom odom frequency in sim time

values.description:
![log_control.gif](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8zodKzn/images/3945315640-log_control.gif)

Differences from Gazebo classic:

* Seeking used to also update the iteration number. Now it resets iterations to zero.
* It's not possible to set `forward` for logs
* `LogPlaybackControl` and `WorldControl` messages work interchangeably. I'm considering adding a new message type, maybe `TimeControl`, which combines both, and deprecating the other 2.
* There's nothing preventing users from rewinding and seeking during regular simulation mode. I've added warnings to all the systems which I thought could be affected by jumps back in time. Jumping forward has no warning, and systems just treat it as a really large time step. The idea is that we can implement rewind and seek for these systems in the future, and we don't want to prevent users from supporting this on their systems.

## Command line

Try it out:

* While playing back a log (or not!), rewind:

`ign service -s /world/shapes/playback/control --reqtype ignition.msgs.LogPlaybackControl --reptype ignition.msgs.Boolean --timeout 5000 --req 'rewind: true'`

* Seek:

`ign service -s /world/shapes/playback/control --reqtype ignition.msgs.LogPlaybackControl --reptype ignition.msgs.Boolean --timeout 5000 --req 'seek: {sec: 140}, pause: true'`


## Systems

Systems can detect rewinds by checking:

* `if (_info.simTime == std::chrono::steady_clock::duration::zero())`
* `if (_info.dt < std::chrono::steady_clock::duration::zero())`

To detect pause:

* `if (_info.paused)`

To detect time jump while paused (`dt` is zero during regular pause):

* `if (_info.paused && _info.dt != std::chrono::steady_clock::duration::zero())`

---

Needs [this ign-cmake PR](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-cmake/pull-requests/172/) to clear cppcheck.
values.title: Rewind / reset and seek

summary.raw:
![log_control.gif](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8zodKzn/images/3945315640-log_control.gif)

Differences from Gazebo classic:

* Seeking used to also update the iteration number. Now it resets iterations to zero.
* It's not possible to set `forward` for logs
* `LogPlaybackControl` and `WorldControl` messages work interchangeably. I'm considering adding a new message type, maybe `TimeControl`, which combines both, and deprecating the other 2.
* There's nothing preventing users from rewinding and seeking during regular simulation mode. I've added warnings to all the systems which I thought could be affected by jumps back in time. Jumping forward has no warning, and systems just treat it as a really large time step. The idea is that we can implement rewind and seek for these systems in the future, and we don't want to prevent users from supporting this on their systems.

## Command line

Try it out:

* While playing back a log (or not!), rewind:

`ign service -s /world/shapes/playback/control --reqtype ignition.msgs.LogPlaybackControl --reptype ignition.msgs.Boolean --timeout 5000 --req 'rewind: true'`

* Seek:

`ign service -s /world/shapes/playback/control --reqtype ignition.msgs.LogPlaybackControl --reptype ignition.msgs.Boolean --timeout 5000 --req 'seek: {sec: 140}, pause: true'`


## Systems

Systems can detect rewinds by checking:

* `if (_info.simTime == std::chrono::steady_clock::duration::zero())`
* `if (_info.dt < std::chrono::steady_clock::duration::zero())`

To detect pause:

* `if (_info.paused)`

To detect time jump while paused (`dt` is zero during regular pause):

* `if (_info.paused && _info.dt != std::chrono::steady_clock::duration::zero())`

---

Needs [this ign-cmake PR](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-cmake/pull-requests/172/) to clear cppcheck.
summary.html:
Differences from Gazebo classic:

  • Seeking used to also update the iteration number. Now it resets iterations to zero.
  • It's not possible to set forward for logs
  • LogPlaybackControl and WorldControl messages work interchangeably. I'm considering adding a new message type, maybe TimeControl, which combines both, and deprecating the other 2.
  • There's nothing preventing users from rewinding and seeking during regular simulation mode. I've added warnings to all the systems which I thought could be affected by jumps back in time. Jumping forward has no warning, and systems just treat it as a really large time step. The idea is that we can implement rewind and seek for these systems in the future, and we don't want to prevent users from supporting this on their systems.

Command line

Try it out:

  • While playing back a log (or not!), rewind:

ign service -s /world/shapes/playback/control --reqtype ignition.msgs.LogPlaybackControl --reptype ignition.msgs.Boolean --timeout 5000 --req 'rewind: true'

  • Seek:

ign service -s /world/shapes/playback/control --reqtype ignition.msgs.LogPlaybackControl --reptype ignition.msgs.Boolean --timeout 5000 --req 'seek: {sec: 140}, pause: true'

Systems

Systems can detect rewinds by checking:

  • if (_info.simTime == std::chrono::steady_clock::duration::zero())
  • if (_info.dt < std::chrono::steady_clock::duration::zero())

To detect pause:

  • if (_info.paused)

To detect time jump while paused (dt is zero during regular pause):

  • if (_info.paused && _info.dt != std::chrono::steady_clock::duration::zero())

Needs this ign-cmake PR to clear cppcheck.

values.description:

values.description:
The `ign-gazebo` command line tool was deprecated on version 2 on pull request #296, and now it's being removed on version 3.

While removing things, I realized the a test was still using the old command line tool for OSX, due to issue #25. This brings the question of whether we maybe want to keep using gflags just for OSX?
values.title: [Citadel] Remove deprecations (mainly gflags)

summary.raw:
The `ign-gazebo` command line tool was deprecated on version 2 on pull request #296, and now it's being removed on version 3.

While removing things, I realized the a test was still using the old command line tool for OSX, due to issue #25. This brings the question of whether we maybe want to keep using gflags just for OSX?
summary.html:
The ign-gazebo command line tool was deprecated on version 2 on pull request #296, and now it's being removed on version 3.

While removing things, I realized the a test was still using the old command line tool for OSX, due to issue #25. This brings the question of whether we maybe want to keep using gflags just for OSX?

values.description:
Main changes are:

* Use a more precise value of pi/2 for the orientation of wheels
* Set fdir1, without which `<mu>` and `<mu2>` are not interpreted correctly
* Scale the wheel separation by `1.24`. This I computed by dividing the commanded angular velocity by the measured angular velocity from the IMU. 

The vehicle steers well without having to set the slip parameters.

I noticed that the RTF was about 50% on my computer. Having 8 wheels per vehicle seems to strain the contact constraint solver in DART.

## To Test
Run
```
ign gazebo -v 4 -r examples/worlds/track_drive.sdf  
```

In another terminal, 
```
ign topic -t "/model/vehicle_blue/cmd_vel" -m ignition.msgs.Twist -p "linear: {x: 2.0}, angular: {z: 1.0}"
```

To check the angular velocity,
```
ign topic -e -t /world/track_drive/model/vehicle_blue/link/base_link/sensor/imu_sensor/imu/
```
values.title: Improve steering behavior of example tracked vehicle

summary.raw:
Main changes are:

* Use a more precise value of pi/2 for the orientation of wheels
* Set fdir1, without which `<mu>` and `<mu2>` are not interpreted correctly
* Scale the wheel separation by `1.24`. This I computed by dividing the commanded angular velocity by the measured angular velocity from the IMU. 

The vehicle steers well without having to set the slip parameters.

I noticed that the RTF was about 50% on my computer. Having 8 wheels per vehicle seems to strain the contact constraint solver in DART.

## To Test
Run
```

```

In another terminal, 
```

```

To check the angular velocity,

summary.html:
Main changes are:

  • Use a more precise value of pi/2 for the orientation of wheels
  • Set fdir1, without which <mu> and <mu2> are not interpreted correctly
  • Scale the wheel separation by 1.24. This I computed by dividing the commanded angular velocity by the measured angular velocity from the IMU.

The vehicle steers well without having to set the slip parameters.

I noticed that the RTF was about 50% on my computer. Having 8 wheels per vehicle seems to strain the contact constraint solver in DART.

To Test

Run

ign gazebo -v 4 -r examples/worlds/track_drive.sdf

In another terminal, 

ign topic -t "/model/vehicle_blue/cmd_vel" -m ignition.msgs.Twist -p "linear: {x: 2.0}, angular: {z: 1.0}"

To check the angular velocity,

ign topic -e -t /world/track_drive/model/vehicle_blue/link/base_link/sensor/imu_sensor/imu/

values.description: There is a potential for concurrent access to the internal view cache in the EntityComponentManager.  This adds protection from multiple threads updating views concurrently.
values.title: Add mutex to protect views from potential concurrent access

summary.raw: There is a potential for concurrent access to the internal view cache in the EntityComponentManager.  This adds protection from multiple threads updating views concurrently.
summary.html: There is a potential for concurrent access to the internal view cache in the EntityComponentManager. This adds protection from multiple threads updating views concurrently.

values.description:
The camera follow feature defaults to following an entity in the entity’s local frame. This PR adds an additional `<world_frame>` parameter to fix the camera orientation and position wrt the entity it’s following.

This is useful for example when following a box that rolls down a hill. With the default frame configuration, the camera rolls around the box when in follow mode. We previously worked around that issue by setting `<p_gain>` to 0, see [here](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/pull-requests/430/add-follow-mode-to-gui/diff#comment-117102773), but it’s not ideal since it affects the speed of camera movement and eventually the camera would not be able to follow the object.

Here’s the behavior of of running the `rolling_shapes.sdf` world with `<p_gain>` of 0.05:

`world_frame: false`

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8zodKzn/images/1435634590-camera_follow_local.gif)
‌

`world_frame: true`

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8zodKzn/images/451263956-camera_follow_world.gif)
‌

Update: [25b2507](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/commits/25b2507ea7bca2bbab405b9c6a7b13a36f6b1b05): Also added support for configuring the camera follow offset position
values.title: Support camera follow in world frame

summary.raw:
The camera follow feature defaults to following an entity in the entity’s local frame. This PR adds an additional `<world_frame>` parameter to fix the camera orientation and position wrt the entity it’s following.

This is useful for example when following a box that rolls down a hill. With the default frame configuration, the camera rolls around the box when in follow mode. We previously worked around that issue by setting `<p_gain>` to 0, see [here](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/pull-requests/430/add-follow-mode-to-gui/diff#comment-117102773), but it’s not ideal since it affects the speed of camera movement and eventually the camera would not be able to follow the object.

Here’s the behavior of of running the `rolling_shapes.sdf` world with `<p_gain>` of 0.05:

`world_frame: false`

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8zodKzn/images/1435634590-camera_follow_local.gif)
‌

`world_frame: true`

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8zodKzn/images/451263956-camera_follow_world.gif)
‌

Update: [25b2507](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/commits/25b2507ea7bca2bbab405b9c6a7b13a36f6b1b05): Also added support for configuring the camera follow offset position
summary.html:
The camera follow feature defaults to following an entity in the entity’s local frame. This PR adds an additional <world_frame> parameter to fix the camera orientation and position wrt the entity it’s following.

This is useful for example when following a box that rolls down a hill. With the default frame configuration, the camera rolls around the box when in follow mode. We previously worked around that issue by setting <p_gain> to 0, see here, but it’s not ideal since it affects the speed of camera movement and eventually the camera would not be able to follow the object.

Here’s the behavior of of running the rolling_shapes.sdf world with <p_gain> of 0.05:

world_frame: false

‌

world_frame: true

‌

Update: 25b2507: Also added support for configuring the camera follow offset position

values.description:
This PR adds two new components:

* `JointPositionReset`
* `JointVelocityReset`

These components act directly on the physics engine, resetting the simulation state of the selected joint. As discussed in [PR#246](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/pull-requests/246/add-jointcontroller-system/diff), the usage of this feature should not be encouraged since fiddling with the internal state of the simulator generally is not a good practice. Though, if done responsibly, it is a feature that has diverse use cases.

As an example, it is currently possible to insert a model in a running simulation with a given pose. However, I didn’t find any way to apply also a specific joint configuration. These new components allow to obtain such state.

There’s also downstream code of Gazebo Classic that use this features and might need in the future to reset the joint state.
values.title: JointPositionReset and JointVelocityReset components

summary.raw:
This PR adds two new components:

* `JointPositionReset`
* `JointVelocityReset`

These components act directly on the physics engine, resetting the simulation state of the selected joint. As discussed in [PR#246](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/pull-requests/246/add-jointcontroller-system/diff), the usage of this feature should not be encouraged since fiddling with the internal state of the simulator generally is not a good practice. Though, if done responsibly, it is a feature that has diverse use cases.

As an example, it is currently possible to insert a model in a running simulation with a given pose. However, I didn’t find any way to apply also a specific joint configuration. These new components allow to obtain such state.

There’s also downstream code of Gazebo Classic that use this features and might need in the future to reset the joint state.
summary.html:
This PR adds two new components:

  • JointPositionReset
  • JointVelocityReset

These components act directly on the physics engine, resetting the simulation state of the selected joint. As discussed in PR#246, the usage of this feature should not be encouraged since fiddling with the internal state of the simulator generally is not a good practice. Though, if done responsibly, it is a feature that has diverse use cases.

As an example, it is currently possible to insert a model in a running simulation with a given pose. However, I didn’t find any way to apply also a specific joint configuration. These new components allow to obtain such state.

There’s also downstream code of Gazebo Classic that use this features and might need in the future to reset the joint state.

values.description:

values.description:
Added a LogVideoRecorder system that automates the process of generating video recordings from playback.

I added a `example/scripts/log_video_recorder` demo to show how to use the system, see the `README.md` file for instructions on how to run the demo. One .mp4 video will be created by entity specified \(through name or region\). The system params are described in[LogVideoRecorder.hh](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/src/c9d1efef4338f324cca12267e8d2a2f87b7556ab/src/systems/log_video_recorder/LogVideoRecorder.hh#lines-39)
values.title: Add log video recorder

summary.raw:
Added a LogVideoRecorder system that automates the process of generating video recordings from playback.

I added a `example/scripts/log_video_recorder` demo to show how to use the system, see the `README.md` file for instructions on how to run the demo. One .mp4 video will be created by entity specified \(through name or region\). The system params are described in[LogVideoRecorder.hh](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/src/c9d1efef4338f324cca12267e8d2a2f87b7556ab/src/systems/log_video_recorder/LogVideoRecorder.hh#lines-39)
summary.html:
Added a LogVideoRecorder system that automates the process of generating video recordings from playback.

I added a example/scripts/log_video_recorder demo to show how to use the system, see the README.md file for instructions on how to run the demo. One .mp4 video will be created by entity specified (through name or region). The system params are described inLogVideoRecorder.hh

values.description:
Needs ~~[this SDF PR](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-requests/581/dont-override-path-with-parent-path/diff)~~.

Relative paths work for actors spawned via the `create` service, and included in SDF worlds.

Also fixed `allow_renaming` - I didn't dig to find out why, but only changing the name after creating the entity was leaving the original name in the Ogre node.

Without this fix, the actor added to `fuel.sdf` would fail to load. Can be tested with:

`ign  gazebo -v 3 fuel.sdf`
values.title: [Citadel] Relative path URIs for actors

summary.raw:
Needs ~~[this SDF PR](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-requests/581/dont-override-path-with-parent-path/diff)~~.

Relative paths work for actors spawned via the `create` service, and included in SDF worlds.

Also fixed `allow_renaming` - I didn't dig to find out why, but only changing the name after creating the entity was leaving the original name in the Ogre node.

Without this fix, the actor added to `fuel.sdf` would fail to load. Can be tested with:

`ign  gazebo -v 3 fuel.sdf`
summary.html:
Needs this SDF PR.

Relative paths work for actors spawned via the create service, and included in SDF worlds.

Also fixed allow_renaming - I didn't dig to find out why, but only changing the name after creating the entity was leaving the original name in the Ogre node.

Without this fix, the actor added to fuel.sdf would fail to load. Can be tested with:

ign gazebo -v 3 fuel.sdf

values.description:
depends on the following pull requests:

* [~~sdformat pull request #585~~](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-requests/585/add-emissive_map-to-material-sdf/diff)
* [~~ign-fuel-tools pull request #105~~](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-fuel-tools/pull-requests/105/convert-emissive-map-file-path/diff)
* [~~ign-msgs pull request #155~~](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-msgs/pull-requests/155/add-emissive_map-field-to-materialproto/diff)

    * ~~this broke ign-msgs4 ABI. Implemented a hack in~~ [~~7f936db~~](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/commits/7f936db8227d2b62d871cd09af349e4d2f762f21) ~~to work around the missing~~ `emissive_map` ~~field~~
    * update [cf8a460](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/commits/cf8a460cc5642c5e862cd5758f60788b06357c2c): bumped to use ign-msgs5
    
* [~~ign-rendering pull request #207~~](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-rendering/pull-requests/207/add-support-for-emissive-map/diff)

Update gazebo to parse emissive\_map property introduced in the PRs above.

Also updated the `fuel_textured_mesh.sdf` example world to include a light fixture model with `emissive_map` property set. Here’s a screenshot:

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8zodKzn/images/2958954839-fuel_emissive.png)
‌
values.title: Parse material emissive map

summary.html:
depends on the following pull requests:

  • sdformat pull request #585
  • ign-fuel-tools pull request #105

  • ign-msgs pull request #155

    • this broke ign-msgs4 ABI. Implemented a hack in 7f936db to work around the missing emissive_map field
    • update cf8a460: bumped to use ign-msgs5

  • ign-rendering pull request #207

Update gazebo to parse emissive_map property introduced in the PRs above.

Also updated the fuel_textured_mesh.sdf example world to include a light fixture model with emissive_map property set. Here’s a screenshot:

values.description:
Allows battery to recharge through user defined sdf parameters: 

<enable\_recharge>: turn on/off recharge function

<charging\_time>: decides the amount of current to be supplied when charging, I = c / t

<soc\_threshold>: starts recharge when battery state of charge falls below the threshold
values.title: Rechargeable battery model

summary.raw:
Allows battery to recharge through user defined sdf parameters: 

<enable\_recharge>: turn on/off recharge function

<charging\_time>: decides the amount of current to be supplied when charging, I = c / t

<soc\_threshold>: starts recharge when battery state of charge falls below the threshold
summary.html:
Allows battery to recharge through user defined sdf parameters:

<enable_recharge>: turn on/off recharge function

<charging_time>: decides the amount of current to be supplied when charging, I = c / t

<soc_threshold>: starts recharge when battery state of charge falls below the threshold

values.reason: Sorry folks, I messed up the versioning and there’s no easy way to fix it other than opening a new branch. I'm closing this and gonna open a new one that merges into ign-gazebo2.

values.description:
While working on Scene3D, I noticed that the system’s `Update` function was never called when the world only contains static models. This means we don't get any stats info from `UpdateInfo `which would be useful for doing things like animating actors or destroying markers when life time ended.

I tested the change with  a complex subt world with only static tunnels and it does not look like the RTF is affected.

A new test was added to verify that msgs are now received on the state topic in an empty world with a static ground plane.
values.title: Update SceneBroadcaster to publish state msg for world with only static models

summary.raw:
While working on Scene3D, I noticed that the system’s `Update` function was never called when the world only contains static models. This means we don't get any stats info from `UpdateInfo `which would be useful for doing things like animating actors or destroying markers when life time ended.

I tested the change with  a complex subt world with only static tunnels and it does not look like the RTF is affected.

A new test was added to verify that msgs are now received on the state topic in an empty world with a static ground plane.
summary.html:
While working on Scene3D, I noticed that the system’s Update function was never called when the world only contains static models. This means we don't get any stats info from UpdateInfowhich would be useful for doing things like animating actors or destroying markers when life time ended.

I tested the change with a complex subt world with only static tunnels and it does not look like the RTF is affected.

A new test was added to verify that msgs are now received on the state topic in an empty world with a static ground plane.
